qas.question: What do vaccines need to work?
What type of vaccines have saved millions of lives?
What types of vaccines have been phased out?

answers.text: Vaccines made from attenuated whole cells or lysates

qas.question: What do polysaccharides need to work?
What type of polysaccharides have saved millions of lives?

plausible_answers.text: Vaccines made from attenuated whole cells or lysates

qas.question: What types of polysaccharides have been phased out?
Vaccines made from what have been replaced by less protein carriers?

plausible_answers.text: activation of macrophages, the production of antibodies, inflammation, and other classic immune reactions

qas.question: What happens when a host includes polysaccharides?

context: Vaccines rely on <a0_0><b3_0>immune modulation or augmentation<b3_0/><a0_0/>. Vaccination either excites or reinforces the immune competence of a host to ward off infection, leading to the <b7_0>activation of macrophages, the production of antibodies, inflammation, and other classic immune reactions<b7_0/>. <a1_0><b4_0>Antibacterial vaccines<b4_0/><a1_0/> have been responsible for a drastic reduction in global bacterial diseases. <a2_0><b5_0>Vaccines made from <b6_0>attenuated whole cells or lysates<b6_0/><b5_0/><a2_0/> have been replaced largely by less reactogenic, cell-free vaccines consisting of purified components, including capsular polysaccharides and their conjugates, to protein carriers, as well as inactivated toxins (toxoids) and proteins.
